definition: to have friendly relationships/circle of friends
to hand over/to deliver/to pay (money)/to turn over/to make friends/to intersect (lines)/variant of 跤[jiao1]

sentences.english: The first part mainly introduces Cai Xiang's life experiences and excursion.
sentences.chinese: 第一部分介紹蔡襄的生平與交遊。

sentences.english: Jeremy used to have a large circle of friends, but now he likes being alone.
sentences.chinese: 傑里米以前交遊甚廣，但現在他喜歡獨處。

sentences.english: Among them, the second part is about the peregrination of Yang Shen in Yun nan.
sentences.chinese: 其中，第二部分專寫楊慎的遊歷及交遊情況。

sentences.english: Jeremy used to have a large circle of friends but now he likes being alone.
sentences.chinese: 傑里米以前交遊甚廣，但現在他喜歡獨處。

sentences.english: The second chapter elaborates Wang Zao making friends and to its poetry creation influence.
sentences.chinese: 第二章論述汪藻的交遊及對其詩歌創作的影響。

sentences.english: Chapter two will analyse and comment him on his behavior to make friends.
sentences.chinese: 第二章對李之儀的交遊行爲進行分析和評論。

sentences.english: Makes friends widely, was close with the literary arena relations then.
sentences.chinese: 交遊廣泛，與當時的文壇關係密切。

sentences.english: The second part is Wei Zhuang's social intercourse.
sentences.chinese: 第二部分爲韋莊蜀中交遊考。

sentences.english: He is a man of wide acquaintance.
sentences.chinese: 他是一個交遊廣闊的人。

sentences.english: These intercommunion activities improved the development in history and geography research on west part of China.
sentences.chinese: 這些學術交遊活動，促進了西北史地研究的深入。

definition: Shen Yue (441-513), writer and historian during Liang of Southern dynasties 南朝梁, compiler of History of Song of the Southern dynasties 宋書|宋书
friend from whom you can seek advice

various sages/refers to the classical schools of thought, e.g. Confucianism 儒[ru2] represented by Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3] and Mencius 孟子[Meng4 zi3], Daoism 道[dao4] by Laozi 老子[Lao3 zi3] and Zhuangzi 莊子|庄子[Zhuang1 zi3], Mohism 墨[mo4] by Mozi 墨子[Mo4 zi3], Legalism 法[fa3] by Sunzi 孫子|孙子[Sun1 zi3] and Han Feizi 韓非子|韩非子[Han2 Fei1 zi3], and numerous others
junior scholar or pupil in imperial China
Gentlemen! (start of a speech)/Ladies and Gentlemen!
what one has seen and heard/knowledge/one's experience
